questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida of 32 weeks presented with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus was tender and the cardiotocograph showed fetal distress. However, the mother is hemodynamically stable. What is the grade of placental abruption in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Grade 2

The given clinical picture is suggestive of grade 2 abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery.

questions.text: Woman presents with numbness and paraesthesia along the anterolateral thigh two days after vaginal delivery. Which nerve is likely involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve

The given clinical features are suggestive of meralgia paraesthetica which is caused by injury to the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve. The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve is at risk of injury during prolonged pushing with hip flexion as the nerve is compressed under the inguinal ligament. It is the most common obstetrical neuropathy after vaginal delivery, followed by femoral nerve involvement.

choices.text: Give surfactant and wait till 36 weeks
Do Doppler everyday to check for reversion

questions.text: A female presents with 35 weeks and 3 days of gestation, AFI = 5 and there is no end-diastolic blood flow. What is the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immediate termination

The given case scenario is suggestive of fetal compromise. The management in this patient is immediate termination of pregnancy. Since this pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks, it can be terminated by cesarean section.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to an antenatal clinic for the first time during the second trimester. In view of a family history of thyroid disorders, a thyroid function test is sent for. Altered levels of which of the following would not be a cause for concern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Total T3 level

Total T3 levels are altered throughout pregnancy. Total T3 and total T4 increase due to stimulation of thyroid tissue by hCG during the early period of gestation. However, there is no change in free T3 and T4 due to an increase in thyroid-binding globulin (TBG). This leads to a transient fall in TSH during the early weeks of gestation. The level of TSH becomes normal during the second and third trimester.

choices.text: Low levels with prolonged doubling time
High levels with decreased doubling time

questions.text: A woman presented with complaints of amenorrhoea for 6 weeks and a history of prior ectopic pregnancy. Serial serum beta hCG levels were estimated in her. Which of the following findings will increase the suspicion of ectopic gestation in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Low levels with prolonged doubling time

Low levels of ẞ hCG and prolonged doubling time increase the suspicion of ectopic pregnancy. Urine pregnancy test is very sensitive and found positive in most ectopic pregnancies. Hence, serial serum ẞ hCG levels are estimated to detect ectopic pregnancy. In early normal pregnancy, the doubling time of ẞ hCG concentrations in plasma is 1.4 to 2 days.

questions.text: During your time in the labor room, you performed a vaginal examination on a primigravida female. The exam showed that the anterior cervix had a soft consistency, was dilated to 3 cm, and measured 3 cm in length. In this case, you would assign a Bishop score of 1 to which of these cervical characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Station -2

The Bishop Score is used to assess cervical favorability for labor induction. It includes five components, each scored 0–3:

Dilatation = 3 cm → Score: 2

Soft consistency → Score: 2

Anterior position → Score: 2

Station = –2→ Score: 1 ← This is the one that gets a score of 1.

choices.text: Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels
Deep tendon reflexes should be present

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 34 weeks of gestation is admitted for preeclampsia with severe features, and you have administered MgSO4, as prophylaxis. Which of the following is not a part of monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels

Routine measurement of serum magnesium levels is not typically required unless clinical signs of toxicity (e.g., loss of deep tendon reflexes, respiratory depression, decreased urine output) are present. MgSO4 is used as an anticonvulsant in the management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe preeclampsia. It can also be used as a tocolytic to stop preterm labor. The therapeutic level of magnesium in eclampsia is 4-7 mEq/L.

choices.text: Start oral labetalol and monitor as outpatient
Administer magnesium sulfate and prepare for delivery

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman, G2P1, at 34 weeks’ gestation presents with headaches and blurred vision. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. There is no history of hypertension prior to pregnancy. She has 2+ lower extremity edema.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Administer magnesium sulfate and prepare for delivery

This patient has severe preeclampsia (BP ≥160/110, symptoms like headache/vision changes, and significant proteinuria). Magnesium sulfate is used for seizure prophylaxis. In severe cases after 34 weeks, delivery is the definitive treatment.

questions.text:
26-year-old woman presents with lower abdominal pain and vaginal spotting. Her last menstrual period was 6 weeks ago. She has a positive pregnancy test. Transvaginal ultrasound does not show an intrauterine pregnancy, and her serum β-hCG is 2,200 mIU/mL.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ectopic pregnancy

At a β-hCG >1,500–2,000 mIU/mL, an intrauterine pregnancy should be visible on transvaginal ultrasound. The absence of an intrauterine pregnancy suggests ectopic pregnancy, especially with symptoms and positive test.

choices.text: Perform McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman is undergoing vaginal delivery. After delivery of the head, the shoulders fail to deliver despite gentle traction. The fetal head retracts against the perineum (“turtle sign”).

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Perform McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure

Explanation: This is shoulder dystocia, a true obstetric emergency. McRoberts maneuver (hyperflexing the mother’s hips) and suprapubic pressure are first-line maneuvers to relieve the obstruction.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman, G3P2, at 36 weeks gestation presents with sudden onset of painful vaginal bleeding. She also reports abdominal pain and decreased fetal movements. Her BP is 90/60 mmHg, HR 110 bpm. On exam, the uterus is firm and tender.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Placental abruption

Painful vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and fetal distress suggest placental abruption. Placenta previa causes painless bleeding. Uterine rupture often occurs in women with a history of cesarean or uterine surgery.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 35 weeks gestation presents with nausea, malaise, and right upper quadrant pain. Her labs show:
    •    AST: 420 U/L
    •    ALT: 380 U/L
    •    Platelets: 85,000/μL
    •    Total bilirubin: 3.2 mg/dL
    •    Glucose: 58 mg/dL
    •    Creatinine: 2.0 mg/dL
    •    PT/INR: elevated
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

Both HELLP and AFLP present in late pregnancy with transaminitis and thrombocytopenia, but hypoglycemia, severe coagulopathy, and acute kidney injury are more suggestive of AFLP. Prompt delivery is required in both conditions.

choices.text: Low molecular weight heparin and low-dose aspirin

questions.text:
33-year-old woman with a history of 3 consecutive first-trimester pregnancy losses is currently 10 weeks pregnant. She has no chronic illnesses. Workup reveals a positive lupus anticoagulant and anticardiolipin antibodies.

Which of the following is the most appropriate management during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Low molecular weight heparin and low-dose aspirin

This patient meets clinical and laboratory criteria for antiphospholipid syndrome (APS). The standard of care to reduce risk of pregnancy loss in APS is prophylactic LMWH + low-dose aspirin.

choices.text: Begin broad-spectrum antibiotics and proceed with delivery
Delay delivery until 34 weeks if fetal monitoring is reassuring

questions.text:
25-year-old G1P0 at 30 weeks’ gestation presents with ruptured membranes for 36 hours. She now has a fever of 38.9°C, maternal tachycardia, uterine tenderness, and fetal tachycardia on monitoring.

What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Begin broad-spectrum antibiotics and proceed with delivery

Explanation: This is preterm premature rupture of membranes (PPROM) complicated by chorioamnionitis (intraamniotic infection). The presence of infection indicates immediate delivery, regardless of gestational age. Antibiotics are started, but delivery is not delayed.

choices.text: Amnioreduction of the larger twin’s sac

questions.text:
A 26-year-old G1P0 woman at 21 weeks with monochorionic diamniotic twins undergoes an ultrasound. One twin has polyhydramnios, a distended bladder, and is significantly larger. The other twin has oligohydramnios and appears growth-restricted.

What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Laser photocoagulation of placental vessels

This is twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS), caused by abnormal vascular connections in a shared placenta. The definitive treatment is fetoscopic laser ablation of the connecting vessels to reduce morbidity and mortality.

questions.text:
36-year-old woman with a history of a prior classical cesarean section presents at 38 weeks in active labor. She suddenly complains of severe abdominal pain. Fetal heart rate shows bradycardia. On exam, the uterus is firm, and fetal parts are palpable abdominally. There is minimal vaginal bleeding.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Uterine rupture

Classic signs of uterine rupture include sudden pain, loss of fetal station, abnormal fetal heart rate (especially bradycardia), and palpable fetal parts through the abdominal wall. It’s more likely with a prior classical (vertical) caesarean

choices.text: Continue monitoring and reassess in 30 minutes
Discontinue oxytocin and administer IV fluids

questions.text:
A 30-year-old G2P1 woman is in active labor at 6 cm dilation. The fetal heart tracing shows recurrent late decelerations, absent variability, and no accelerations. A scalp stimulation test is attempted and fails to produce an acceleration. She is on low-dose oxytocin.

What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prepare for emergent cesarean delivery

This is a Category III tracing (absent variability + recurrent late decels), indicating fetal hypoxia/acidemia. Scalp stimulation not eliciting an acceleration confirms fetal compromise. Emergent cesarean delivery is indicated.

questions.text:
A 38-year-old woman is in labor at term when she suddenly becomes dyspneic, hypoxic, and hypotensive. She then develops tonic-clonic seizures. Labs show DIC (low platelets, elevated PT/PTT, low fibrinogen). Fetal bradycardia is noted.

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Amniotic fluid embolism

Explanation: Sudden cardiopulmonary collapse, seizures, DIC, and fetal compromise during labor are hallmark features of amniotic fluid embolism, a rare but catastrophic obstetric emergency. Immediate supportive care and delivery are key.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman, G2P2, presents to the emergency department 10 days after a spontaneous vaginal delivery with heavy vaginal bleeding. She reports soaking multiple pads per hour over the last 3 hours. She has mild lower abdominal cramping but no fever or foul-smelling discharge. On exam, she is pale, HR 112 bpm, BP 92/58 mmHg. Her uterus is mildly enlarged and tender on bimanual exam.
Hemoglobin is 7.8 g/dL. Ultrasound shows heterogeneous echogenic material in the endometrial cavity.

What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Perform dilation and curettage (D&C)

This is a classic case of secondary (late) postpartum hemorrhage, occurring >24 hours to 6 weeks postpartum. The most common cause is retained products of conception (RPOC), especially with an enlarged, tender uterus and ultrasound findings. The appropriate next step is surgical evacuation (D&C). Antibiotics are considered only if signs of endometritis are present (e.g., fever, purulent discharge).

choices.text: Start uterotonics and prepare for uterine artery embolization
Perform immediate manual replacement of the uterus
Apply bimanual uterine massage and wait for spontaneous correction

questions.text:
A 30-year-old G2P2 woman has a spontaneous vaginal delivery after an uncomplicated labor. Soon after the delivery of the placenta, she develops profuse vaginal bleeding and severe lower abdominal pain. On exam, she is pale, diaphoretic, hypotensive (BP 70/40 mmHg), and tachycardic (HR 130 bpm). The uterine fundus is not palpable abdominally, and a smooth, red, round mass is protruding from the vagina.

What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Perform immediate manual replacement of the uterus

This is a classic presentation of uterine inversion, often caused by excessive traction on the umbilical cord or fundal pressure during placental delivery. Key signs include:
    •    Sudden hemorrhage
    •    Shock out of proportion to blood loss
    •    Absent uterine fundus abdominally
    •    Red, smooth mass protruding from vagina
Immediate management is manual replacement of the uterus (Johnson maneuver) — ideally before uterotonics are given, because uterotonics can cause sustained contraction and make replacement more difficult. After the uterus is repositioned, uterotonics are used to help it contract and stay in place.
    •    Antibiotics may be given prophylactically afterward.
    •    Hysterectomy is a last resort in refractory cases or if there is necrosis.
